body: I'm not very familiar with C or else I'd do it myself, but it would be great if the 'Press ENTER or type command to continue' line didn't print every time you ran an external command. It's something you only need to see once, and seeing it every time gets rather annoying. I think this message should just be removed and the behaviour it describes (hitting a key to go back to vim after running a shell command) be folded into the documentation (if it's not there already).

comment_data.body: Wait, you just want the _message_ removed, but you still want the pause? I'd actually like to think about making it easier to control whether a pause occurs at all (although it's kind of a moot point now that we have `jobstart()`).
Yeah, the pause can be left, but the message itself is rather annoying.

I would rather be able to do away with both the pause AND the message.

I always found them both very annoying.

> which may brake things but seems to work for ':!man man', with 'K' and for filtering with '!'):

@Shugyousha So if the command is interactive (like `man`) it will hide Vim until the user ends `man`? What if the command is not interactive, like `:!ls` ?

> So if the command is interactive (like man) it will hide Vim until the user ends man?

Yupp

> What if the command is not interactive, like :!ls ?

The Nvim screen will not even flicker since `ls` returns so fast... :-) In my opinion you should not run shell commands without side effects for your Nvim session through Nvim itself. Just using another shell is just as easy and is exactly equivalent (except that you may have to open a new shell or change to an open one).

This proposed behavior fits very well in my workflow so I am all for it. I can understand that other users have different requirements. That's why having the behavior configurable is probably the best approach.

Well, sometimes people just want to run a quick command to see the output and then `q` back to Vim. 

I think there's an improvement that can be made without compromising any existing use cases: if a command returns empty, don't show a "Press ENTER" prompt; instead, just echo a "shell returned <error code>" status message.

Or maybe don't show anything at all: plugins/users can already listen to `ShellCmdPost` if they want to do further handling (I would advocated shipping Neovim with a default handler for this, though).

Getting rid of "Press ENTER" entirely is not a good idea in my opinion, because it will make the existing use-case of "I just want to check the results of this command" a multi-step process. On the other hand, users who _don't_ want to see the results of a command have these options:
- dispatch.vim
- Neovim's `jobstart()`

Perhaps we should think about adding a special async version of `:!` that uses `jobstart()`. Maybe one of these:

```
:>!
:@!
:&!
```

The existing `>`, `@`, and `&` commands don't allow bang and probably never will.

`:^` and `:)` are also available, although they might drive the VimL parser insane (not to mention VimL syntax highlighting).

not return anything on stdout or only on stderr just show the "shell

stderr in that case).

I think these are nice options to have but I personally never want to
see the output of a program I run using ! so making it the default would
make sense for me. I don't think I am alone but that is why we are
discussing the issue.

> Perhaps we should think about adding a special async version of `:!`
> that uses `jobstart()`. Maybe one of these:
> 
> ```
> :>!
> :@!
> :&!
> ```
> 
> The existing `>`, `@`, and `&` commands don't allow bang and probably
> never will.
> 
> `:^` and `:)` are also available, although they might drive the VimL
> parser insane (not to mention VimL syntax highlighting).

I would prefer not adding any more syntax. Having a configurable option
to make the ! command not wait for input (at least in certain cases)
seems like the cleaner solution to me.

I would like to know other people's opinion on this.

- outsider perspective -
  I like the idea that it would jump to the screen _only_ if it had unhandled output. One of the "marketing(?)" ideas I love about NeoVim is "removing cruft". The pause is something that really takes away the shine from Vim and it's one of those little changes that will make a big impact on how people perceive the project when they first start using it.

I would also say that defaulting to _not_ showing it - even when there is unhandled output - would break expectations and raise a bunch of wtfs. That is unless it says "command returned 0" or something of that sort.
Sorry for the bullet and bad formatting. I forgot to preview and thought I could edit it afterwards.

As a user of :! to execute commands, I agree with the conclusions of Shugyousha and DanTheColoradan. I use the pause and prompt to execute commands for commands with a text output, but I would welcome an option to not have the pause and prompt. Opening another terminal is not always convenient (eg. work over ssh or using a small screen).

I would LOVE to see the abolition of the Press Enter to continue nonsense.  At the very least, an option to disable it.  

Let's say for example you have UltiSnips installed, which has an autocmd triggered on every cursor move, and your Python installation is broken, so on every cursor move UtliSnips will give an error.  How utterly insane.  vim would be perfectly usable (just without UltiSnips) with a broken Python.  It shouldn't become completely unusable just because a single plugin isn't happy.
@alexdunn :+1:

@alexdunn 
In the issue you mention, is the plugin actually using ':!' to execute commands, or is it only showing a similar message and prompt given by another mechanism? Isn't the issue more that the plugin uses (or has to use?) an unadapted mechanism to execute commands? Or that it doesn't handle errors properly?

As a user facing feature the prompt is not nonsense for everyone. Some people do use this feature, so I don't think it should be completely removed. An option to configure this behaviour seems like a good idea. I personally don't mind about the default value for the option. I think it depends on the neovim policy chosen for the new defaults. Backward compatibility would suggest keeping the default behaviour similar to vim; user friendly defaults would lean toward skipping the prompt all the time or when nothing was output.

Personally I'd be fine with a 'user friendly' default for this. 'Advanced' users will know to look for ":help" when something doesn't work as they expect after switching to neovim. As for plugins, they should have a way to handle errors properly without having to modify the behaviour of user facing commands.
I have a PR in progress that help with this.

So annoying to have that message for shell commands. When echoing two lines `:echo "line 1" | echo "line 2"` with `cmdheight=2` the message is not displayed. How on earth it is enforced for shell commands, even if the output can perfectly fit into the command line.

> I think there's an improvement that can be made without compromising any existing use cases: if a command returns empty, don't show a "Press ENTER" prompt; instead, just echo a "shell returned " status message.

Couldn't agree more.
Can this `Press ENTER` message and pause be removed from the source tree everywhere so that I never, ever see it? It shows up in many more places than just shell commands.
Adding an option to avoid it should be feasible. I'm sure you could predict that removing it totally is not an option.

This message has always bugged me too, but the only way to get rid of it is to completely change how nvim presents notifications to the user. One solution I had considered is to use a special `:terminal` buffer that will receive every message from the editor, which would allow messages(command output and error) to be presented to the user without blocking the UI with the press ENTER state. More details are here: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/2076#issuecomment-76595194

> I think there's an improvement that can be made without compromising any existing use cases: if a command returns empty, don't show a "Press ENTER" prompt; instead, just echo a "shell returned " status message.

I think this is very reasonable

I also get same issue with 
```viml
func! s:test(...)
   set nomore
   echo "sss\nsss"
endf
au VimEnter * call timer_start(400, function('s:test'))
```

in neovim I will see
```
sss                                                                                                                                            
sss
Press ENTER or type command to continue
```

For anybody who finds this in a web search, I got around this by adding an additional `<CR>` at the end of my command.  It's not exactly what is being asked for, but for many it should be a suitable workaround.

This has been an issue for me when attempting to use `vim.api.nvim_echo()` to display information that usually ends up being wider than the window size. Setting `cmdheight` prior to calling `vim.api.nvim_echo()` with the intent to reset it post-echo didn't seem to help. Based on the information in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/16462, I wrote the following function that truncates the middle section of the message in order to display a message that has some start/end context and also doesn't elicit the forsaken 'Press ENTER or type command to continue'.
```lua
local test_message = "This long message will not display on a single line on most screens. If it does, ensure your window size is smaller."

local function non_disruptive_echo(message)
    if #message > vim.v.echospace then
        local trunc_fill = "..."
        local first_part = string.sub(message, 1, vim.v.echospace/2 - #trunc_fill)
        local second_part = string.sub(message, #message - math.floor((vim.v.echospace/2)), #message)
        vim.api.nvim_echo({{first_part .. trunc_fill .. second_part}}, false, {})
    else
        vim.api.nvim_echo({{message}}, false {})
    end
end

non_disruptive_echo(test_message)
```
Output on a very small window: `This long messag...dow size is smaller.`

It would be really good to have an option to disable the 'Press ENTER...' prompt when using `vim.api.nvim_echo()` and still display the full string to be echoed.
The option can be added.  But I don't know it is better solution.
@kylefhartzenberg You can use `nomore` option for it.

@Shougo Could you please provide an example of how to use the `nomore` option? The documentation for [nvim_echo](https://neovim.io/doc/user/api.html#nvim_echo()) doesn't seem to mention anything about it so I am not sure what you have in mind.
